node.text: Video by @dzalcman / There was a lot of traffic this morning on BIA Highway 33 through the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 20, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, tree and nature.

node.text: Photos by Luke Sharrett @howdyluke / U.S. Navy foresters Rob McGriff and Rhett Steele check on a plot of forest whose timber was recently harvested at Naval Support Activity Crane in Crane, Indiana. The men are part of a group of professional foresters employed full-time by the Navy to ensure the long term health and biodiversity of the Navy base’s sprawling forest. #natgeo #whiteoak #usnavy #nsacrane #forestry

node.text:
Photos by @cristinabaussan / With the increase in the number of deportations from the United States, I spent weeks with deportees in El Salvador to document how they are re-adapting to life in a culture they grew up far away from and are finding community in the people and traditions that remind them of their American home.

1. Walter Blanco, 50, moved to Maryland at age 13 to reunite with his mother. He was deported to his hometown of Intipucá, El Salvador, in 2001 after an aiding and abetting conviction stripped him of his green card. “In the U.S., there are doctors, lawyers, and engineers,” he said. “Here too.”

2. Elena Mejía, Blanco’s mother, migrated to the United States in search of economical stability and later became a U.S. citizen. “My mom was a tailor,” Blanco said. “The best at making dresses.” But when she arrived to Maryland as a young mother, Mejía became a housekeeper at various hotels to send money home to her family in Intipucá, El Salvador. When Blanco was deported in 2001, Mejía sent him a suit that he wears on special occasions. 

These images were made on assignment for @natgeo as part of a series on migration in Central America launching this summer. Follow me @cristinabaussan for more stories of tenderness in the face of adversity.

node.text: Photos by Luke Sharrett @howdyluke / A pair of White Oak trees grow in Constitution Grove at Naval Support Activity Crane in Crane, Indiana. White Oak timber growing on base is harvested by the US Navy for use aboard the wooden-hulled frigate U.S.S. Constitution. Built in 1797, the historic vessel is docked in Boston’s Charlestown Navy Yard and periodically requires new white oak timber to maintain a state of good repair. #natgeo #whiteoak #nsacrane #forestry #ussconstitution

node.text: Photos by @dzalcman / This is a copy of a letter that was sent by Rosebud Lakota Chiefs White Thunder and Swift Bear in 1880 when they learned of the death of their children Ernest and Maud at the Carlisle Indian Industrial School. “They are far very far away from us. We cannot bear to have them sleep so far from this earthly home, our hearts will grieve too long if we do not have what is left of them.” The letter went unanswered. For more coverage from their journey home, more than 140 years later, follow @dzalcman and @bmorinstories.

node.text: Video by @dzalcman / A color guard of Native women service members watch over the funeral of nine Rosebud Lakota youth on July 17. The children were sent to the Carlisle Indian Industrial School, the first of hundreds of institutions in the US meant to forcibly assimilate Indigenous youth into white, western culture. Countless students died while at these schools — either through the spread of disease, malnutrition and mistreatment, or failed attempts to run away. These nine children — Rose Long Face (Little Hawk), Dennis Strikes First (Blue Tomahawk), Maud Little Girl (Swift Bear), Alvan (Kills Seven Horses), Dora Her Pipe (Brave Bull), Friend Hollow Horn Bear, Warren Painter (Bear Paints Dirt), Lucy Take the Tail (Pretty Eagle), and Ernest Knocks Off (White Thunder) — all died while attending Carlisle and were buried there for over 140 years. This week, they were repatriated back to their homelands and buried at the veteran cemetery on the Rosebud Reservation. For more documentation of their journey home, follow @dzalcman & @bmorinstories

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and outdoors.

node.text:
Photos by @cristinabaussan / With the increase in the number of deportations from the United States, I spent weeks with deportees in El Salvador to document how they are re-adapting to life in a culture they grew up far away from and are finding community in the people and traditions that remind them of their American home.

1. Mayra Machado, 36, was first deported to El Salvador in January 2017 after being convicted for writing false checks at age 18. Desperate to reunite with her kids, she didn’t stay long before migrating again. But she was detained by immigration agents and was sent back for the second time to El Salvador in January 2020 after more than two years in Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) detention. She hasn’t seen her children in person since. Machado says she has no plans to attempt a third journey to the U.S.. “I refuse to give ICE another day of my life,” she said.  
2. When Machado was deported in 2020, she carried this purse with only three items in it – her phone, so that her kids could reach her, her lipstick, and a pair of sunglasses to feel protected from the outside world. 

These images were made on assignment for @natgeo as part of a series on migration in Central America. Follow me @cristinabaussan for more stories of tenderness in the face of adversity.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and outdoors.
Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 17, 2021.
Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 17, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text: Photo by @shonephoto Robbie Shone / The loss of the ice caves is not just about losing a beautiful underground landscape, but also about losing an important scientific resource. Like tree rings that can be analysed for climate information, the layers within the ice can also provide climate information. The nature of their formation means the records reveal details of past winter seasons. Organic material trapped within the ice can be radiocarbon dated to find out when the ice was deposited. #EndOfTheIceCaves #IceCaves @NatGeo @Natgeointhefield

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 16, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Photo by @acacia.johnson / A walrus skull rests in a field of wildflowers on Round Island, Alaska. This remote island in the Bering Sea—known as Qayassiq, or "place to go in a kayak" in Yup'ik—is home to thousands of male walrus that come to rest on its shores every summer. 

Since 1960, the island has been protected as part of the Walrus Islands State Game Sanctuary, where a permit program allows small groups of visitors to camp on the island every summer to observe walrus in the wild. It also remains an important hunting ground for Yup'ik communities who coordinate a subsistence hunt for walrus every fall, continuing the traditions that have taken place here for over 5,700 years.

Taken on assignment for an upcoming @natgeo story about this remarkable place.

#walrus #alaska #walrusislands #qayassiq #roundisland

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 16, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text: Photo by @shonephoto Robbie Shone / It’s quite simply a race against time to document the beautiful European ice caves before they melt away and disappear due to climate change. We have just returned from Hochschneid ice cave, located in the Höllengebirge, Austria. Here, climate scientist Tanguy Racine from the University of Innsbruck, admires the pristine ice at the bottom of the cave. To the right, is ice that formed when water entered the cave and froze. To the left, behind Tanguy, is ice formed from snow that fell into the cave from the entrance, creating a snow cone. #EndOfTheIceCaves #IceCaves @natgeointhefield @natgeo

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 16, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text: Photo by @dzalcman / I’m currently with a caravan making its way from Carlisle, PA to the Rosebud Reservation with nine Rosebud children who were taken to the Carlisle Indian Industrial School and buried there for over a century. As we pass through other Native nations, the caravan has stopped for communities to pay their respects before they return home for a feast and funeral this weekend.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on July 15, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text: Photo by @dzalcman / This caravan of Rosebud youth & community members are bringing back their nine relatives who were buried at the Carlisle Indian Industrial School for the past 140 years. Carlisle was the first boarding school for Native children opened in the US, with the explicit mandate of coercive assimilation. We’ve made it from Carlisle, PA to Iowa City, IA and will reach the Rosebud Reservation in South Dakota tomorrow. On Saturday, the tribe will hold a funeral for the nine children and lay them to rest in their historic homelands. Follow along as @bmorinstories and I continue to document their journey.
